[[Samuel Boyle, Jr.]] coached his second season for the Keydets, which featured only one gameâa 39â0 win over {{cfb link|year=1899|team=Washington & Lee Generals|title=Washington & Lee}}.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cfbdatawarehouse.com/data/coaching/alltime_coach_game_by_game.php?coachid=3146&year=1899|publisher=[[College Football Data Warehouse]]|accessdate=June 26, 2011|first=David|last=DeLassus|title=Coaching records game-by-Game: S.A. The 1899 football season at VMI was cut short by an outbreak of typhoid fever on the campus. As reported by one account: "VMI had time to crush only Washington and Lee 39â0 before the 1899 season was abruptly ended by an outbreak of typhoid fever which closed the Institute for six weeks."<ref name=Marshall>{{cite web|title=George C. Marshall and the Virginia Military Institute|publisher=George C. Marshall Foundation|pages=11â12|url=http://www.marshallfoundation.org/about/timeline/documents/marshallatvmi.pdf}}</ref> On October 16, 1899, all 250 cadets were sent to their homes on account of the outbreak.<ref>{{cite news|title=Typhoid at Virginia Institute|newspaper=The Free Lance|date=October 19, 1899|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=sI5UAAAAIBAJ&sjid=qY8DAAAAIBAJ&pg=5643,3566460&dq=virginia-military+typhoid&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=MILITARY INSTITUTE CLOSED: Cadets Furloughed For Thirty Days Because Typhoid Fever|newspaper=The Sun, Baltimore, Md.|date=October 17, 1899|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1734736822.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Oct+17%2C+1899&author=&pub=The+Sun+(1837-1985)&desc=MILITARY+INSTITUTE+CLOSED&pqatl=google}}</ref> At least one cadet died in the outbreak,<ref>{{cite news|title=DEATH OF CADET LEMOINE|newspaper=The Sun, Baltimore, Md.|date=October 19, 1899|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1734741232.html?FMT=CITE&FMTS=CITE:AI&type=historic&date=Oct+19%2C+1899&author=&pub=The+Sun+(1837-1985)&desc=DEATH+OF+CADET+LEMOINE&pqatl=google}}</ref> and the school was not re-opened until November 28, 1899 -- after the football season had ended.<ref>{{cite news|title=Typhoid Fever at College: Report of the State Board of Health on Outlook at the Virginia Military Institute|newspaper=The News and Courier|date=November 17, 1899|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=T1VJAAAAIBAJ&sjid=9gkNAAAAIBAJ&pg=1797,4800848&dq=virginia-military+typhoid&hl=en}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=MILITARY INSTITUTE: Report Of The State Board Of Health ON THE FEVER OUTBREAK The Disease Was Imported To The Premises -- Remedies Suggested - School To Open November 28|newspaper=The Sun, Baltimore, Md.|date=November 17, 1899|url=http://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/baltsun/access/1734788722.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:AI&type=historic&date=Nov+17%2C+1899&author=&pub=The+Sun+(1837-1985)&desc=MILITARY+INSTITUTE&pqatl=google}}</ref>
VMI's sole opponent for the year, Washington & Lee, finished the season with a record of 0 wins, 4 losses, and 1 tie. The "Keydets" of VMI handed their one opponent the biggest defeat (by score) of the season.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://cfreference.net/cfr/school.s?id=81&season=1899|publisher=College Football Reference|title=Washington & Lee University (VA) - 1899|accessdate=July 1, 2011}}</ref>
In the lone game of the season, W. B. "Bruce" Montgomery, Jr., the captain and quarterback for VMI, scored a [[touchdown]] on an 80-yard carry.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://news.google.com/newspapers?id=cPpBAAAAIBAJ&sjid=3bgMAAAAIBAJ&pg=6076,3575520&dq=virginia+military+institute&hl=en|publisher=[[Baltimore American]]|title=A Game at Lexington|accessdate=June 26, 2011|date=October 12, 1899}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|title=Bomb|year=1900|publisher=Virginia Military Institute|pages=76â77|url=http://www.archive.org/stream/bomb1900virg#page/76/mode/2up}}</ref><ref name="Baltimore Sun" /> Montgomery would go on to the next season to be team captain and assist with coaching duties.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://chroniclingamerica.loc.gov/lccn/sn84024441/1900-09-11/ed-1/seq-6/;words=footbal+Bruce+football+Virginia+Montgomery+Military|publisher=[[The Washington Times|The Washington Evening Times]]|date=September 11, 1900|page=6|accessdate=June 29, 2011|title=Training for Football}}</ref>
One of the individuals who played for the VMI football team in 1899 and 1900 was [[George C. Marshall]], who went on to be [[Chief of Staff of the United States Army|Chief of Staff of the Army]], [[United States Secretary of State|Secretary of State]], and [[United States Secretary of Defense|Secretary of Defense]].<ref name=Marshall/><ref>{{cite book|title=The Bomb (VMI yearbook)|year=1900|publisher=VMI|page=76|url=http://www.archive.org/stream/bomb1900virg#page/76/mode/2up}}</ref>
